11155: Pariah.author: CorkBulb
11155: Pariah.text_parsed:
Deftblade Elite reduces combat damage only, and requires a free to use effectively. Try someone like Cho-Manno and you've got a great set up, especially considering he can't be killed with damage, unlike our Deftblade Elite. It would require a "destroy" or exile effect to remove him, such as our infamous Doom Blade or Path to Exile

Then, of course, we have the obvious Stuffy Doll, who can only be removed by exile, or have the enchantment destroyed.

Remember this will not effect loss of life such as from Exsanguinate.

At least, it will stop the damage from a single attack. You could always put this on an opponent's creature as a makeshift removal to discourage attacks. I don't think they will be attacking you if you put this on their Platinum Angel, especially if they have 0 or less life.

4/5 for usefulness

11155: Pariah.author: TheWrathofShane

Choose yourself with stuffy doll and then drop this on it, infinite loop when you tap it. Then add Lifelink, and you got yourself infinite life.

But a much more solid combo, stuffy doll plus Guilty Conscience. Results in one shot to target opponent.

Maybe in mutliplayer you would rather go for infinite life, or maybe even go for both.

11232: Deflection.author: nemokara
11232: Deflection.text_parsed:
"3 = R, and a step down in rarity. By this logic, Necropotence should cost 1R and be a basic land."

Oh, come now. That's quite a leap. Yes, Swerve has both dropped in rarity and cheaper mana-wise (but don't forget it's also MORE color-intensive/restrictive, which usually comes with a bit of a CMC discount), and there has been plenty of power creep. This is just how the game has changed and adjusted as the years have gone by.

But remember that there are also effects that have been made MORE expensive. Gone are the days of 2- or 3-mana land destruction (the standard nowadays seems to be 4 mana minimum, usually 5 with an extra effect) and 2-mana counterspells with no restriction (these are the closest cards to Counterspell that we've gotten in recent years: Corrupted Resolve, Deprive, Unified Will, and Stoic Rebuttal - all four require some deckbuilding restriction or other hoops to jump through). And don't forget Demonic Tutor - a two-mana unrestricted tutor directly to your hand, as an uncommon. No way that wouldn't be rare or even mythic rare nowadays. Likewise, I think WOTC underestimated the power of Necropotence, and if they printed a similar effect today would either make it weaker or harder to pull off. ... or just make it a chase mythic rare. :S

11238: Disenchant.author: NuckChorris
11238: Disenchant.text_parsed: 7th Edition art is the best. Name one card from 7th with bad art.
11238: Disenchant.text_posted: 7th Edition art is the best. Name one card from 7th with bad art.

11238: Disenchant.author: tenkaze
11238: Disenchant.text_parsed:
I hope you mean just for this card and not the whole set. 7th had some of the worst art the game has ever seen.

EDIT: Okay, I'll back up my claim. Greed. Disrupting Scepter. The Diamonds. Crystal Rod. Air Elemental. Rampant Growth. Coat of Arms. They're not all bad as in "lacking artistic skill," they're bad as in "doesn't accurately depict what is conveyed by the text" or "conveys the subject in a bland and unflavorful fashion." Rampant Growth shows a guy getting strangled by vines. Rampant Growth, then, is expected to be a kill spell, but as you know, it isn't. Coat of Arms shows one person standing alone. Coat of Arms is terrible if you're playing with only one creature. Disrupting Scepter is a card that represents an item that can tear things out of people's minds, but both the user and the victim seem no more excited than if the scepter were a paper towel roll. I've seen finger paintings that convey more emotion and excitement. Compare 7th's Air Elemental with the 10th or Portal Second Age versions and it's clear which is the worst. An Air Elemental is a creature made of air, not some ugly blue man sticking his tongue out at me. This is made even worse by its flavor text, which was apparently written by a Juggalo.

Of course, there were tons of great Rebecca Guay pieces in 7th edition, so it wasn't all terrible. And this is actually my favorite art for Disenchant, with Ice Age in a close second. So I'm not making a categorical statement saying that all 7th edition art is bad, but I haven't yet seen another set that overall gave off such a sterile and uninteresting vibe.

11254: Earthquake.author: Aaron_Forsythe
11254: Earthquake.text_parsed:
Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #47, 12/9/10

Like Lightning Elemental, Earthquake is a card that would likely be in my “perfect Core Set” that I’d want to put in a time capsule. Unlike Lightning Elemental, Earthquake has a huge impact on Standard environments that it’s in, so it sees print less often these days as we like decks full of little ground creatures to be good sometimes. There’s probably some good reason why we’re okay with Wrath of God/Day of Judgment being more or less perpetually in print but we modulate Earthquake, but I don’t know that I’ve ever actually thought it through. I just remember hearing early on in my career that “Earthquake isn’t a card we want around all the time,” and that made sense to me on some level without having a bunch of explanation behind it.

The card was in print continually from its inception in Alpha all the way through Seventh Edition, all of which happened before I worked here. It was removed for Eighth Edition and didn’t resurface again until M10. It says a lot about the card that was one of the first cards ever created, yet it holds up perfectly today in all aspects--flavor, mechanics, and power.

I went into Multiverse looking for comments on the Seventh Edition Earthquake in particular to see if there were other cards being bandied about for this slot in the set, or if they had begin to worry about its impact, but there are no comments in that file because (1) Seventh Edition predates the current version of our Multiverse database, and (2) Core Sets weren’t built in databases back then anyway, but rather in physical card binders, as they contained only reprints. People would move cards in and out by hand, look at how the set felt, and discuss things with the team lead. There was no real need to play the set in limited--not much, anyway--as core sets weren’t used in that capacity in any large events. As a result, there wasn’t much electronic commenting going on.

I remember when I first got to Wizards seeing the binder slowly coming together for Eighth Edition, but I think that practice was abandoned shortly thereafter in favor of building the set in a database, a practice I enjoy much more if for no reason other than the historical records such a practice generates.

11256: Elder Druid.author: DrJack
11256: Elder Druid.text_parsed:
Green just isn't allowed to be green anymore. Every cool thing green used to have got stolen and tossed into blue's "slice of the color pie". (or in some cases, red's slice.)

Green used to be good at untapping things (especially lands and creatures) as well as tapping things down to a certain extent (e.g. Winter Blast, a great card).

Green also used to be clever with tricks like Camouflage, Natural Selection,Sylvan Library, Vitalize, and so on, rather than being the embodiment of all things mindless and predictable. Green is now the "Idiot's Color" for underachiever kids who oogle at the sight of huge, undercosted trampling beasts and annoying 1/1 creature tokens. And REALLY ugly artwork.

11268: Fallen Angel.text_parsed: The original Nantuko Husk, and my personal favorite of the two. If this goes unblocked, you can sacrifice all your other creatures to win you the game in most cases. 4.5/5.
11268: Fallen Angel.text_posted: The original [autocard]Nantuko Husk[/autocard], and my personal favorite of the two. If this goes unblocked, you can sacrifice all your other creatures to win you the game in most cases. 4.5/5.

11268: Fallen Angel.author: Mr_Hendry
11268: Fallen Angel.text_parsed:
The flying ability definitely sets this card apart from its counterparts.

It may not get the extra defense like Nantuko Husk but the flying means it's less likely to be blocked.

It may not get permanent counters like Carrion Feeder but the extra strength and flying make it more powerful.

The timing requirements for Crovax the Cursed make it worse than this card.

Phyrexian Ghoul is just a functional reprint of Nantuko Husk (actually the other way around) but without the extra insect subtype. The same can be said fro Vampire Aristocrat but with him you get the useful vampire subtype. Of course none of these have flying like are lovely angel.

Lastly, Sarland Thrinax is pretty slick since it only requires one of each color and offers +2/+2 per creature. It does not compare however to our flying mistress.

I's say second place goes to Carrion Feeder, he's pretty mean for a one drop, especially when you considers those beef-ups are permanent.

I just would love to get some lifelink going on with this angel.

11285: Force Spike.author: blurrymadness
11285: Force Spike.text_parsed:
@almighty-abacus
That's not "ragequitting" IMO. You 5-for-1'd him. That's equivalent to a one sided wrath mid-late-game or something else huge. He had no chance of winning. I quit early somewhat often because a combo won't "go off" and I'll have wasted too many resources to attempt it again.. or something.

The overusage of "ragequit" is a bit annoying because there's a huge difference. I DO ragequit some games. Others I concede. How is it a term that's been respectfully and rightly used for centuries is over-written, by what amounts to an insult, in every context.


With that, Force spike is decent for establishing early control against good decks. Whenever I think it's in a deck, I don't play a first turn card unless I don't care about it.

11356: Jalum Tome.author: TastetheJace
11356: Jalum Tome.text_parsed:
Not totally. Yes it is repeatable, but Mental Discipline requires you to discard a card as part of the casting cost, before resolution. That means:
1) It's even worse if it's countered while on the stack (hello Stifle)
2) You can't discard the card that you draw should you need to (graveyard tech, mana flood, etc)
3) You have less of an idea to which card you really want to part with since you must discard before you draw. This can result in you discarding a card that you best guess you can't use, only to then draw a card that would enable its use. Had you drawn first, you could have discarded a different card instead.

11377: Leshrac's Rite.author: DarthParallax
11377: Leshrac's Rite.text_parsed:
the FLAVOR of Landwalk, and particularly Swampwalk, has always been phenomenal (Evil things pass through Darkness), but I've always felt it was somewhat lacking in gameplay Value terms.

Both Protection and Trample tend to feel like better keywords that you'd want on a creature, and Shadow unfortunately feels like a bit too much for the "Rogue" flavor of Swamp and Island walks.
Forestwalk shows up on "Rangery" cards a lot. Plainswalk is just bad though, bad flavor, bad value, bad everything, and that's why it only shows up on 3 cards. The problem is they made Landwalk a Cycle of Keywords, and I think the game would be much better off if they consolidated the 5 Landwalk Keywords into one, tuned with flavor that it could be put it on Shadowy things with Swampwalk, or Rangery things with Forestwalk, or Mountaineers and Fish.


The Keyword name I suggest is: Wanderer. :) This quite excellently fits all the needs of the previous Landwalk mechanics.

The second problem with the way Land-Transforming works in Magic is that rarely is a card like Evil Presence worth playing a whole to get, but WOtC has been making progress adding small effects or making things Global like with Blood Moon and Urborg. Landwalk and Land Transforming don't need a LOT of help, but they DO need SOME. Right now they are a tad too superfluous when Flying is usually just so much easier to come by, and other forms of Unblockability tend to be more worth the mana price and card advantage investment. Lumping all the Landwalk together into 'Wanderer' makes the smallest enough of changes to make the mechanic really interesting and more useable. :)

11398: Meekstone.author: Japicx
11398: Meekstone.text_parsed:
I love that this was printed before the phrase "blue-white control" became a stock phrase in every Magic player's vocabulary. Blue and white meet perfectly with this card.

White has ways to make hordes of soldiers and, more importantly, vigilance. One of these with Captain of the Watch or Mobilization (or Serra's Blessing if you have some problem with Soldiers) will make your opponent curse himself for not running more artifact removal and putting so much stock in the hugeness of his creatures. With Meekstone out, good old Serra Angel quickly puts Baneslayer to shame and dominates the board. As good as lifelink is, it can't always substitute for vigilance.

Blue is good for lending support in the form of Trinket Mage and other artifact-search cards, as well as providing ways to counter the artifact removal that could end the one-sided lockdown and turn the tide of the game against you.

It's probably one of the best control cards in the game, though I can understand why Wizards wouldn't want to reprint it, seeing as how a card that shuts down most decks that rely on the novel idea of "winning by attacking" is absolutely no fun to play against.

11398: Meekstone.text_parsed:
No one mentioned the funny combo with Thran Weaponry?
Play Kobolds, Meekstone, Thran Weaponry, and this. Most creatures can't untap, but yours can! Yours are also free, so feel free to Winter Orb everyone as well! Heck! Put down things like mana breach and overburden.

You don't need your lands once the combo is assembled and your opponents have to sit and watch. Combine with propaganda and iron maiden for alternative win cons.

Hilarious deck as your opponents basically have to watch helplessly as you build your mighty empire. Most artifact and enchant hate can't get through easily, and even if they would? You have spell pierce and force spike ready :D

11398: Meekstone.author: Fanaticmogg
11398: Meekstone.text_parsed:
As the name might suggest, this card goes nicely with Weakstone. Anything with 1 power is useless, anything with 3 or more power only gets in one attack, and 2-power creatures have their damage halved.

It works especially well since the Weakstone only works during the combat phase, which means that the creatures regain their power in time for Meekstone to keep them tapped.

11469: Regeneration.author: fissionessence
11469: Regeneration.text_parsed:
Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #14 - 7/11/2011 - Regeneration

One of the many 'keyword cards' that grants a keyword ability to a creature, either for a turn, or as an Aura, permanently. This card and Regenerate, its instant counterpart from M10, cover the spectrum of 'Aura version' and 'instant version', ala Flight and Jump. This one is also interesting in that regeneration isn't technically a keyword, but a keyword action, but I think it could still fit pretty confidently in with the rest of the keyword cards.

While some of the keyword cards have a unique flavor (like Jump or Lance), many of them are simply, "Here's a Lego piece for that keyword—go build a creature." Regeneration, as a mechanic, is flavorful, but this card doesn't add any of its own spice . . . which is fine. The M12 card Trollhide is a slightly more expensive version, which adds +2/+2, and has its own flavor (My creature gets troll skin instead of just a generic healing factor!), and even is a mechanical revisitation of Savage Silhouette from Zendikar, which also had a unique flavor, although quite esoteric.

[b]Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #14 - 7/11/2011 - Regeneration[/b]

This card and [autocard]Regenerate[/autocard], its instant counterpart from M10, cover the spectrum of 'Aura version' and 'instant version', ala [autocard]Flight[/autocard] and [autocard]Jump[/autocard]. 11494: Shanodin Dryads.author: MisterAction
11494: Shanodin Dryads.text_parsed:
For a creature that's undetectable in woodland areas, this card sure has gotten less and less stealthy with each iteration.

First art: Vaguely lady-shaped tree
Second art: Green Mystique
This: Floating sparkly naked woman

The only way I can imagine this lady having evasion is if this happens:

"All right Bill, the enemy's coming. Stand your ground and be ready for anyth-"
"WHOA! Check out that one!"
"Sweet heavens, what a looker. With all the time I've spent out alone in this forest, a guy could really..."
"Oh, she's leaving. Dang, I'm gonna be thinking about her for weeks."
...
"Hey Jim... weren't we supposed to block?"

11499: Shield Wall.author: zackhammer
11499: Shield Wall.text_parsed: I like this card because its flavor text expresses the disappointment and cynicism inherent in being a creature summoned in Magic: The Gathering. To be born or to die, to take life at its own pace, to do violence to another whose only crime is to have come into existence by the machinations of another, these are choices we players take for granted. Who's to say that, left to their own devices, Amrou Kithkin and The Fallen might not put aside their differences and be kind to one another? Sangrophage might not act with such seeming malice were it not for the human hand that guides his path, and some scholarly pursuit might await Bloodcrazed Goblin save for our maddening influence. Floral Spuzzem was the last of a breed long dead, a subordinate Prometheus who dares to pluck the flames of sentience from the brow of his creators, whose haughty rebellion ever damned him to the obsolescence and disrepair of the scrap heap. No jolt of reasoning shall ever again turn the cogs of the summoned mind, nor admonishments of bloodshed dull the falling blade.
11499: Shield Wall.text_posted: I like this card because its flavor text expresses the disappointment and cynicism inherent in being a creature summoned in Magic: The Gathering. To be born or to die, to take life at its own pace, to do violence to another whose only crime is to have come into existence by the machinations of another, these are choices we players take for granted. Who's to say that, left to their own devices, [autocard]Amrou Kithkin[/autocard] and [autocard]The Fallen[/autocard] might not put aside their differences and be kind to one another? No jolt of reasoning shall ever again turn the cogs of the summoned mind, nor admonishments of bloodshed dull the falling blade.

11517: Stream of Life.author: Lyoncet
11517: Stream of Life.text_parsed:
"Thanks, I was TRYING to figure out a way to gain a single life on the first turn."

Assuming you're on the draw, you could Forest, Lotus Petal, crack the petal and tap the forest to gain 1. Or if you're using banned/restricted cards, Forest, Lotus Petal, crack the petal, Mana Vault, tap, Mana Vault, Mana Vault, Mana Vault, tap those three for 9 colorless floating, tap the forest and play this for 9 life. (Cut out one Vault if you're on the play.) And then start taking 4 damage per turn.

But personally I like statiefreez's idea of Channeling 19 more.

11517: Stream of Life.author: Travelsonic
11517: Stream of Life.text_parsed:
In a deck with the Basalt Monolith / Power Artifact combo, this can be stupid:-

"I tap and untap Basalt Monolith once. Unless you have a response, I repeat these actions 249 googolplexian times. I pay 1 green and 500 googolplexian colorless mana, play stream of life. I'm now at 500-googolplexian-and-20 life."

Googolplexian: 1 followed by a googolplex 0s
Googolplex: 1 followed by a googol 0s
Googol: 1 followed by 100 0s.
Just so people know these are real numbers, so they don't get chewed out wrongly when using them.

11544: Twiddle.author: kitsunewarlock
11544: Twiddle.text_parsed: A classic. It protects you from damage, gives you a blocker, lets you use that creature's tap ability twice, ramps your mana with cards like Tolarian Academy, Sol Ring or just Tron. It protects you from counter-spells by tapping out your opponent's last island, you can put it on Scepter to get an Icy Manipulator on crack. It lets you use your artifact again and de-activates artifacts like Winter Orb or Howling Mine. There have been many variations of this card, many of which are a tad stronger. But Twiddle will always maintain its status as the first.
11544: Twiddle.text_posted: A classic.  It protects you from damage, gives you a blocker, lets you use that creature's tap ability twice, ramps your mana with cards like [autocard]Tolarian Academy[/autocard], Sol Ring or just Tron.  It protects you from counter-spells by tapping out your opponent's last island, you can put it on Scepter to get an [autocard]Icy Manipulator[/autocard] on crack. They can tap the island for mana but it will fade away between the phases.

11581: Wrath of God.author: DarthParallax
11581: Wrath of God.text_parsed:
50th Vote! :D

This is such an iconic spell that it still retains a 4.95 average on Gatherer, making it one of the very highest rated cards ever. Type in "Rating > 4.95", and the results will fit nearly on one page. All the other ones tend to be "Laundry List" cards that you see all the time in Vintage, sometimes in Legacy if they aren't BANNED, and NEVER anywhere else because they're too old. This has a directly functional reprint in Day of Judgement and we get to play with it in Standard all the time. Probably the most powerful card, on average, that you or any of your friends own, unless you're a big collector that does history on "Broken Stuff that Made History".

12957: Infernal Contract.author: DarthParallax
12957: Infernal Contract.text_parsed:
I can't tell if this would be considered good today or not. I'm not disputing that the effect of drawing four cards is great- that's just amazing- but 3 colored mana and half your life? Would that see standard, or are the cards they make today not powerful enough in their interactions to make it worth it? (I.E. are the combos degenerate enough?) Also it is sorcery speed, though that would matter much much less if it's mana cost were less prohibitive.

Interesting card, but for 3 black mana I'd rather run Necropotence. 3.5 stars because being good then does not always mean would be broken today....

12962: Early Harvest.author: feedbacker
12962: Early Harvest.text_parsed:
This card might as well have an X in it to make it easier to read

lets look at the tempo and uses for this card


it can get you from 4 mana to 5: getting one extra mana is pretty plain, might as well play a more effective (cheaper) card that would do the same

from 5 to 7:
lots of strong cards at 7 that might rival or beat many of those titans and powerful 6 drops your opponent might be player around the same time you are

from 6 to 9 and beyond

this card would be a catalyst for a kill card that will hopefully give you the game, I recommend playing defensive if used in these types of decks


Also you can use this to help mana fix double mana colored card in multi color decks

12970: Final Fortune.author: Azazyel
12970: Final Fortune.text_parsed:
People, you're not casting it on turn two. Think - if you're running mono-red burn and haven't won by your fifth turn, you're most likely done for. If your Elemental Appeal got countered or your Hunted Dragon just got bitchslapped by a Path and you're left staring at your opponent's bolstered army, that's where this card comes in, saving your butt by offering you a second chance.

The drawback, once you think of it, is minimal, because in the decks that would run this, if you didn't win the turn you cast it, you were most likely screwed anyway.

12970: Final Fortune.author: Clavat99
12970: Final Fortune.text_parsed: FInal Fortune is a great card if you use it right. First off, if you use it as a finisher, you can get an easy win. Another use is by having Platinum Angel in play, and then you can use FInal Fortune at any time without losing the game. Emrakul, The Aeons Torn is another great combo with FInal Fortune. When you play it you get another turn, so you can attack with flying for 15, then play a final fortune and you get to do it again. The Annihilator 6 on Emrakul will have your opponents field pretty much clean after you attack the second time, so the second attack is a kill shot mos of the time. Final Fortune is still a dangerous car dunles you can use it right, however.

12970: Final Fortune.author: blurrymadness
12970: Final Fortune.text_parsed:
Something really cool about this card that no one's noticed is that it's AWESOME tech against people taking extra turns because it's an instant. Often a game boils down to the next turn one of the players will win. When the other person crams an extra turn in there you can then put your next turn in before theirs to steal the win.

It's a bit unlikely to happen in very many games, but it IS worth noting. It can also break someone trying to lock you down with extra turns to win. Wait til they've resolved their extra turns (be it panoptic mirror, time walk cards, time sieve cards, etc...) and then take your turn before theirs. Worst that happens is you lose anyway!


That said, it's a great finisher. Being only 2 mana allows the turn you cast it (or previous turn if you cast it during an opponents) to be not-useless as well. Red Decks eat mana to keep the high damage flowing, so having a couple left is nice.

12970: Final Fortune.author: Aquillion
12970: Final Fortune.text_parsed:
@Arachnos: Using Sundial of the Infinite means you will not lose the game with this (thanks to the oddly specific Oracle wording, which isn't how most cards that work this way or worded.)

It says "at the end step of that turn." Sundial of the Infinite skips the end step, which means that the end step of that turn never comes and you never lose the game.

(Note that the Sundial does not work with anything that just says "at the end of the turn", while stuff that just says "the next end step" or "the end step" is just delayed for a turn. But this specifies "the end step of that turn", which means the lose condition can only go off on the end step of that specific turn and will never trigger if that turn's end step is skipped.)

12994: Agonizing Memories.author: Cyberium
12994: Agonizing Memories.text_parsed: Instead of making opponent discard, you force them to put cards on the library, which hinders their time. This is, in fact, an underestimated ability by most. If you can force your opponent to draw cards they already have but couldn't cast (such as expensive cards, or a piece of their combo), it's pretty much as good as getting extra turns for yourself. Don't forget that in an LD deck, this also prevents them from getting to the lands they desperately need.
12994: Agonizing Memories.text_posted: Instead of making opponent discard, you force them to put cards on the library, which hinders their time. This is, in fact, an underestimated ability by most. If you can force your opponent to draw cards they already have but couldn't cast (such as expensive cards, or a piece of their combo), it's pretty much as good as getting extra turns for yourself. Don't forget that in an LD deck, this also prevents them from getting to the lands they desperately need.

It becomes less powerful late in the game though.

13021: Dregs of Sorrow.author: Raexs
13021: Dregs of Sorrow.text_parsed:
At first glance, this isn't all that appealing, what with the {X}{4}{B}. Yeck.
"Why would I do that instead of just Plague Wind?"
Well, use your head, dum-dum. Plague Wind doesn't draw you cards.
Considering the absurd numbers that black mass-mana can conjure, this quickly becomes viable and - in many cases- a very powerful board wiper. Even if X is only 2, that's two threats dealt with and two more cards in hand for a reasonable 7 mana. Although it may not be able to deal with every threat on the board, it gives you plenty of new options for dealing with the survivors.
And just like most X spells, I feel multiplayer EDH is where this black gem really shines.

Damn, those 7th Edition paladins are rad.

13021: Dregs of Sorrow.author: MacBizzle
13021: Dregs of Sorrow.text_parsed:
Here is how these spells with both "targeting effects and non-targeting effects" and spells with "multiple targets" work.
Ashes to Ashes is a good example. The targets need to be chosen before you can cast it. Ashes to Ashes needs to target two non-artifact creatures, exile them, then damage you for five. If both of those targeted creatures disappear before Ashes to Ashes resolves, Ashes to Ashes fizzles and you do not take five damage. If both creatures are there and legal upon resolution, the spell carries out as normal. If only one of the targets are there, you still exile the other and take five damage. A spell with multiple targets needs at least one of its' targets to remain legal for it to resolve. Doesn't matter if you dumped ten mana into this and someone killed a target of yours- you still resolve it with the remaining four targets and draw five cards. If you dump ten mana into this and they sac all five targets, the spell fizzles.

13030: Benthic Behemoth.author: Radagast
13030: Benthic Behemoth.text_parsed:
A prime example of the "Bad Old Days" of Magic's Core Sets. They went through a phase, starting around 5th Edition and ending I think around 8th or 9th where nearly every good, classical, and powerful card was stripped out of the core set and was replaced with underpowerd and overcosted junk instead. Things like Trained Orgg, Vizzidrex (or however you spell that stupid blue 6/6 for 6U that was supposed to "replace" the Mahamoti Djinn), and so on. This underpowered lump of lame is an example of this line of thinking - the core set was supposed to be weak since somehow weak cards were "good" for new players. Right...

Compare to Inkwell Leviathan and cry a bit that this card was ever printed.

13046: Seeker of Skybreak.author: Ideatog
13046: Seeker of Skybreak.text_parsed:
Sorry, Skeptical Mario- each tap causes its own trigger from Insolence, and they are all separate sources. Samite Ministration would only gain you the life from one of them.

@ROBRAM89 -
You enchant the Seeker with Insolence, then tap it. One instance of the Insolance's triggered ability goes on the stack. That is what you are choosing when you choose a source of damage for Samite Ministration, not the enchantment itself. If you untap the Seeker and tap it again, there will be another instance of that ability on the stack which won't be covered by Samite Ministration, because it only allows you to choose one source (which here means one of the two the triggered ability instances on the stack).

A similar example is storm spells. Storm is a triggered ability which creates copies, putting those new copies on the stack. It doesn't replicate the spell itself. So if you, for example, Stifle the storm, you get no copies. But if you use Samite Ministration to prevent the original spell from doing damage ( Grapeshot, for example) It will prevent that spell's damage, then storm will trigger and create copies whose damage will not be prevented, even though they came from a spell whose damage you did prevent.

I hope this helps.
13046: Seeker of Skybreak.text_posted:
Sorry, Skeptical Mario- each tap causes its own trigger from Insolence, and they are all separate sources. Samite Ministration would only gain you the life from one of them.

@ROBRAM89 -
You enchant the Seeker with Insolence, then tap it. One instance of the Insolance's triggered ability goes on the stack. That is what you are choosing when you choose a source of damage for Samite Ministration, not the enchantment itself. If you untap the Seeker and tap it again, there will be another instance of that ability on the stack which won't be covered by Samite Ministration, because it only allows you to choose one source (which here means one of the two the triggered ability instances on the stack). 

A similar example is storm spells. Storm is a triggered ability which creates copies, putting those new copies on the stack. It doesn't replicate the spell itself. So if you, for example, [autocard]Stifle[/autocard] the storm, you get no copies. But if you use Samite Ministration to prevent the original spell from doing damage ( [autocard]Grapeshot[/autocard], for example) It will prevent that spell's damage, then storm will trigger and create copies whose damage will not be prevented, even though they came from a spell whose damage you did prevent.

I hope this helps.

Your storm example is accurate in and of itself, but it isn't similar to this situation. All damage from Insolence comes from a single source, whereas each spell (and each copied spell generated by storm) is a different source entirely unrelated to the original from the time it is put on the stack.

13097: Engineered Plague.author: Werewolf-
13097: Engineered Plague.text_parsed:
SUPER_ROBO_NINJA, if your opponent plays Engineered Plague and chooses "vampire," your Vampire Hexmage will enter the battlefield as a 1/0 creature and be put into the graveyard immediately upon resolving before you have a chance to activate its sacrifice ability UNLESS it comes into play with a +1/+1 counter on it or a static +1/+1 boost (such as from the effect of Bad Moon).

See Force of Savagery for a similar example.

13097: Engineered Plague.author: Thabeanieboy
13097: Engineered Plague.text_parsed: This is such a good card in legacy. It forces an almost instant scoop against the B/W Humans, elf decks, and goblin decks that run around. It can shut down the nimble mongooses and delvers of RUG Delver before they get big, stopping the deck's early game. It can even be of use against blue or esper control decks by naming wizard, being able to kill off Snapcaster Mage, Vendillion Clique, and Dark confidant. My favorite sideboard card in legacy and a really underrated card.

13099: Knight Errant.author: Arachobia
13099: Knight Errant.text_parsed:
People are always talking in comments about how certain cards in core sets like M10 & M11 are important for new players. Will I think this card is a good one for people new to the ranking system on gatherer.

At the time of this post, he has a higher rating then Fledgling Griffin. This may seem weird, to a new player. But Knight Errant is a knight-type and therefore has more synergy with many decks then the griffin. Therefore it is rated higher.

But, of course, if one was not running any knight tribal whatsoever, one would probably rather have the griffin then this in a deck.

why is this rated so low?

fantastic sideboard material.

13117: Intrepid Hero.author: 4wallz
13117: Intrepid Hero.text_parsed:
I remember I was playing a game where this was my last creature on the battlefield. My opponent had Silvos, Rogue Elemental out. I'm @ 6 life. I realize I'm about to loose. But then I remember a very nice rule. When a creature regenerates it taps.
So every time it is his turn I tap this guy to kill his Silvos. He regens him but it doesn't matter because he has to tap & can't attack with him. Needless to say he was ***ed. But this guy is was my MVP! Go old school!
13117: Intrepid Hero.text_posted:
I remember I was playing a game where this was my last creature on the battlefield.  My opponent had Silvos, Rogue Elemental out.  I'm @ 6 life.  I realize I'm about to loose.  But then I remember a very nice rule.  When a creature regenerates it taps.  
So every time it is his turn I tap this guy to kill his Silvos.  He regens him but it doesn't matter because he has to tap & can't attack with him.  Needless to say he was pissed.  But this guy is was my MVP! Go old school!

13117: Intrepid Hero.author: tcollins
13117: Intrepid Hero.text_parsed:
Remember kids, in a pinch you could use pump spells on your opponents creature to enable the destroy effect, example:

Opponent controls a Dark Confidant (2/1 for {1}{B}) that's giving them some pretty hefty card advantage...in response at the end of turn:
{T} Forest -> {G} -> Giant Growth (or similliar spell) targeting the Dark Confidant, making him a 4/3...then {T} Intrepid Hero to destroy it!

Very flavourful and versatile card, for a similar {B} version see Royal Assassin

13129: Elite Archers.author: tcollins
13129: Elite Archers.text_parsed:
Agreed, that flavour doesn't seem very {W}.. (are they recycling dead angel feathers? That would seems more {B}{G} than anything.. or are they hunting angels..? That just doesn't seem white at all.

As for the mechanics of the card itself, instead of playing this, for {5}{W} you could instead get:
Mirror-Sigil Sergeant which can be devastating in the right deck.
Auratouched Mage, just run it with Eldrazi Con***ion and you have a 13/13 with trample and annihilator 2.
Noble Templar with 3 more toughness and vigilance, also has plainscycling.
Not to mention the swarm of better creature that have more {W} colour commitment, such as the often mentioned Baneslayer Angel

There are just better cards out there, the {T} ability is limited at best.
13129: Elite Archers.text_posted:

13129: Elite Archers.author: Kirbster
13129: Elite Archers.text_parsed:
...why did the change the flavour text? The original version at least mentioned why the arrows were fletched like so. It improved accuracy. Naturally, this makes it a good idea. They're a clever bunch, those Urza's block archers.

Then these dopes come along. "They fletch their arrows with the feathers of angels." They also braid their scraggly beards and get lip piercings and make digeridoos out of PVC pipes. Yes, as of 7th edition, they are a band of dirty, no-good hippies who desecrate dead angels because they think it makes them cool. Without that note on accuracy, we have to come up with all of the conclusions by ourselves. Shame.
13129: Elite Archers.text_posted:

13147: Wood Elves.author: Bbone37
13147: Wood Elves.text_parsed:
Holgir, I feel where you are coming from. Woodeleves get a forest, Farhaven any basic. As tcollins pointed out, this is superior if you have access to dual lands and/or shock lands. What I don't understand is reasoning in the comment. "A standard land searcher if you simply need an additional body, don't need a specific colour and want an untapped land. Otherwise search with Farhaven Elf." Farhaven elf has the same CMC, the same p/t, the fetched land ETBs tapped.... except for the duals (that contain forest) vs basic of any color, and Scout subtype vs Druid, they are pretty much exactly the same.

I would run these dudes over Farhaven personally, since they can fetch non-basic Forests.

3.5/5 in monogreen (for nastalgia) or if you are playing with duals/shocks. other than that I would agree with holgir...

13167: Venerable Monk.author: Wanderer25
13167: Venerable Monk.text_parsed:
More terrible art from 7th edition...

Edit: Seriously? Would you like to defend this art instead of just rating down my comment? Ok, WHY is this art bad?

Is it the "my first paint set" color scheme? Is it the flat background that looks like a set backdrop combined with the lack of a convincing mid-ground? Is it the poor composition that splits the image into a cross (vertical axis beginning with the monk's right foot and continuing up along his right sleeve; horizontal axis starting at his left hand, continuing across the horizon line) and totally robs it of any dynamic quality it might have had? Is it the careless positioning of the figures that leaves them completely caught in the frame, with not a single limb extending off of it? Is it the wretchedly drawn gumball tree that is somehow perched right upon the horizon line?

The image tries and utterly fails to portray a dynamic action. It is static, dull, flat, and poorly colored.

Yeah, so that's pretty much it. Don't mess with art history majors, you'll get an essay.

@Shadoflam

Maybe I got a bit carried away on this one, but it's because I passionately enjoy what I do. That's all I ask for in a calling; I honestly hope you can say as much about yours.

Is it the careless positioning of the figures that leaves them completely caught in the frame, with not a single limb extending off of it? Is it the wretchedly drawn gumball tree that is somehow perched right upon the horizon line? 

The image tries and utterly fails to portray a dynamic action. It is static, dull, flat, and poorly colored. 

Yeah, so that's pretty much it. Don't mess with art history majors, you'll get an essay.

@Shadoflam

Maybe I got a bit carried away on this one, but it's because I passionately enjoy what I do. That's all I ask for in a calling; I honestly hope you can say as much about yours.

13171: Knighthood.author: Radagast
13171: Knighthood.text_parsed: With regard to the heavy armor and first-strike, keep in mind that first-strike in the early days of the game was generally seen as using something like a lance to impale the foe before they could get their own melee weapons on you. Hence, "Lance" being the card that granted first-strike. So, knights with first-strike (Black Knight, White Knight, etc.) does make sense.

13171: Knighthood.author: KnightOfSerra
13171: Knighthood.text_parsed:
@Sironos Two points; A. Contrary to popular belief, plate armor doesn't make you move slower. B. Assassins rarely even fought in combat and therefore wouldn't have any use for first strike.

Knights in mtg get first strike primarilly because a knight's preferred weapon while mounted was classically a Lance. Longer weapon means you hit first.

Alternatively knights also get first strike to exemplify their skill in combat. As sombody who loves to study medieval warfare I can honestly say that the best trained warriors in the medieval world were hands down the Knights of Europe.

As far as the card goes, I really like it. I used to use it in my knight deck before concerted effort came out. My only complaint is that Knighthood is pretty near useless in a knight deck. Most knights already have first strike and most knight decks probably run Kinsbaile Cavalier. Still my soldier deck could use a bit of knighting....

15778: Cloudchaser Eagle.author: mrredhatter
15778: Cloudchaser Eagle.text_parsed: Cloudchaser Kestrel is the stronger choice.

15778: Cloudchaser Eagle.author: tezcat
15778: Cloudchaser Eagle.text_parsed:
Yes, you can cast this creature when no enchantments are in play. However, since the effect is not optional (i.e. does not read 'may'), if only one enchantment is in play, it will be targeted and destroyed regardless of who controls it. In short, if you are the only player with enchantments in play, casting this creature will destroy one of your own permanents.

Keep in mind that Cloudchaser Kestrel is the obvious, stronger choice only in mono-White, due to its heavier White requirement (WW instead of W). The Kestrel could still be the better option in a particular non-mono-White deck, but this may not be so obvious.

15796: Opposition.author: greatspearman
15796: Opposition.text_parsed:
@Tavaritz:
Dear Sir,
If I may direct you to Captivating Vampire and Skirsdag High Priest as examples, you'll see that Wizards words it this way literally all the time. My guess for the reasoning for this is so that cards like this where the tap symbol is absent don't confuse new players into trying to tap untapped creatures to pay a cost. It's also to differentiate between the fact that creatures always have to start untapped to tap them for a cost, whereas a creature can always be targeted to be tapped as part of an effect as long as it's a legal target.

I understand that for 7th edition, the designers wanted to create a new type of world, where the four paladins battled for supremacy. Hence why they didn't want to reference characters like Jaya Ballard, Task Mage who wouldn't be a part of that world.

15825: Darkest Hour.author: Mode
15825: Darkest Hour.text_parsed:
without combos it's at most useful when playing against other specific black decks with the common restricted destruction effects, and even then it's only useful if yours isn't already mono-black anyways.

there are some good and semi-useful combos, though:
-the best one of them is likely done with Teysa, Orzhov Scion, to create a saccing-loop. given that you control at least three creatures, you can remove any of your opponents creatures from the game.

-with Darkest Hour, any creature with protection from black (or cards like Raven's Run Dragoon) will be unblockable and have some sort of "creature-shroud".

other useful effects:
-Razorjaw Oni: to disable blocking
-Stronghold Taskmaster or Urborg Shambler to shrink every creature's p/t by 1.
-Light of Day: to create mass Pacifism.
-Reclamation: to most widely prevent attacking

given that your opponents has creatures:
-Nantuko Blightcutter: having protection from black, he's unblockable anyways, and with threashold, he'll grow by 1 for every creature you opponent controls.
-Northern Paladin or Exorcist: to destroy your opponents creatures.
-Spectral Force: to negate its drawback to get a 8/8 tramper for 3GG.
-Pygmy Kavu: for extra cards.
-Black Scarab: at the cost of W you can enchant any creature to get +2/+2 and become unblockable.
-Decomposition: to give your opponents creature a cultimative saccing cost and the lifeloss of 2 when it's put into the gy.
-Starlight: 3 life for every of your opponent's creas.
less useful for this, but still synergizing:
-Reap: to return some cards in your gy to your hand.
-Radiant Essence: to get a 3/5 crature for 1WG.

the following effects synergize with black creatures.
in case not all of your creatures are black, bad moon can turn the rest of them in the right color to be affected by the following cards:
-Lyzolda, the Blood Witch: to draw a card if you sacrifice your creature for 2. combined with Savra, Queen of the Golgari, you can have your opponent sacrifice one of his creatures every time given that you pay 2 life. yet since none of your creatures would be green, that's also some sort of dissonance.
-Crowd of Cinders: to grow in size
-one of the lieges (Ashenmoor Liege, Creakwood Liege, Deathbringer Liege, and Glen Elendra Liege) to boost your creatures p/t by one.
-Dire Undercurrents: to let your opponent discard a card whenever one of yours comes into play.
less useful:
-Bad Moon: to boost every creatures p/t by one.

15826: Nightmare.author: Morgaledh
15826: Nightmare.text_parsed:
@vantha

Nightmare is a horse because in the 1st ed. AD&D Monster Manual it's a horse. And Gygax got the idea, in part, from Fuseli's painting "The Nightmare." In fact, D&D was a massive influence on the Alpha of Magic. it slays me how people don't know these things.
15826: Nightmare.text_posted:
@vantha

15862: Static Orb.author: TheMurderousKitten
15862: Static Orb.text_parsed: Yes, TheWrathofShane, you are missing something. The point of using Lodestone Myr is not to boost the Myr, but to provide an efficient way to tap the Static Orb just before your turn. That way you get to untap all of your stuff each turn and your opponents only get to untap two permanents on each of their turns.
15862: Static Orb.text_posted: Yes, TheWrathofShane, you are missing something.  The point of using [autocard]Lodestone Myr[/autocard] is not to boost the Myr, but to provide an efficient way to tap the Static Orb just before your turn.  That way you get to untap all of your stuff each turn and your opponents only get to untap two permanents on each of their turns.

15863: Coat of Arms.author: yuvalg
15863: Coat of Arms.text_parsed:
It's interesting that foil versions of playable white-bordered cards with distinct art fetch such higher prices than regular, because the foil cards from these white-bordered sets were printed with black borders. In this case, the foil 7th Ed Coat of Arms fetches $30 (compared to $8 in other sets) even though the regular version costs the same $5 as the others.

Another great example of this phenomenon is 7th Edition Serra Angel

15881: Compost.author: Saikuba
15881: Compost.text_parsed: This card is being underrated (unless it is downvoted because it is unfair).  This thing will generate an insane amount of card advantage against a normal mono-black deck.  They have to fall behind in card advantage to kill any of your creatures, any trade in combat becomes a 2 for 1, and if they should discard cards or sacrifice things for any reason, you draw a card.  And since it's an enchantment, the only way they can deal with it is by a first turn duress or something similar.

15882: Yavimaya Enchantress.author: The_Murderauder
15882: Yavimaya Enchantress.text_parsed:
@Zoah: Your comment is messed up in a number of ways.

A) assuming you can tell somebody's gender based "something about the arms and face," plus their hair and "curves" is a bit transphobic, and pretty much wrong.

B) the implication that there's something wrong with people having atypical body types for their gender ("A pity," in your words) is overtly transphobic, also wrong, and just plain mean.

and

C) perhaps the only amusing (and ironic, considering the content of your post) mistake you made: the artist, Terese Nielsen, is female.

tl;dr: you're wrong, and you should feel bad.

25562: Arcane Laboratory.author: SeiferKnight
25562: Arcane Laboratory.text_parsed: Would Arcane Laboratory conflict with cards with Suspend? Like having two cards with one time counter on them, would 'playing' both of them conflict with only being able to play one spell per turn?
25562: Arcane Laboratory.text_posted: Would Arcane Laboratory conflict with cards with Suspend? Like having two cards with one time counter on them, would 'playing' both of them conflict with only being able to play one spell per turn?

25562: Arcane Laboratory.author: djbon2112
25562: Arcane Laboratory.text_parsed: @PhilJol: However, "play", which IS still used in the rules and why it's used in the M10/M11 wording, refers to "casting a spell or playing a land during the Main Phase special action". I'm also no rules expert, but it seems that under these definitions if something with suspend resolves, that's your spell for the turn.
25562: Arcane Laboratory.text_posted: @PhilJol: However, "play", which IS still used in the rules and why it's used in the M10/M11 wording, refers to "casting a spell or playing a land during the Main Phase special action". I'm also no rules expert, but it seems that under these definitions if something with suspend resolves, that's your spell for the turn.

25562: Arcane Laboratory.author: PhilJol
25562: Arcane Laboratory.text_parsed:
@SeiferKnight: A better place ask would be the rules forum, but here is my taken on it:

The word "play" has been updated to "cast". Suspend's first ability (Suspend has three parts, the original cost, the upkeep and counter removal, and the actual playing of the spell), after looking at the rules, doesn't use the stack. So I don't believe that would be considered "casting".

However, the third part reads "When the last time counter is removed from this card, if it’s exiled, play it without paying its mana cost if able. If you can’t, it remains exiled. If you cast a creature spell this way, it gains haste until you lose control of the spell or the permanent it becomes.” I take this to mean that, if the effect successfully happens, you just played the spell.

For reference, "cast" means "To take a spell from where it is (usually the hand), put it on the stack, and pay its costs, so that it will eventually resolve and have its effect." With the third ability of suspend, you are taking the spell, putting it on the stack, and paying its costs.

A lenghtly answer, but an answer nonetheless.

@djbon2112: That was the conclusion I got to. Just with a lengthly explanation.

Beautiful card.

Now I run 4 of them in my blue-green landfall deck, alongside 4x Exploration, 2x Burgeoning, and one Fastbond. 4.5 / 5 in the right deck.

25567: Mana Short.author: Salient
25567: Mana Short.text_parsed:
I hate this card with the passion of a thousand fiery suns.

Why? Because any new player who reads it immediately gets it in their head that Magic is a game of Slapjack.

Every time I see a new player use this card, here's how it's used:
(1) I have priority, and tap down to cast whatever spell.
(2) They wait until right before I show the spell from my hand, looking ready to pounce.
(3) They superquick tap three islands and BAM! they Mana Short me.
(4) I explain, sorry but that's not how the flow of the game proceeds, you don't have priority, you can't cast spells in response to mana abilities, etc -- Magic doesn't work that way, it's not a speedy-play contest.
(5) They frown and go rebuild their deck, and this is the first card to go.

...I sympathize with the new players on this. The card was confusing in its original form, and it's still confusing nowadays with the revised wording. It almost seems designed to trick new players. I'm glad they eventually booted it from the core sets.

25567: Mana Short.author: DarthParallax
25567: Mana Short.text_parsed:
I think this card should come back to the Core Set :/

1. It is DEFINITELY NOT overpowered...but it's BEST CASE SCENARIO is really exciting! :D
It's almost like an Instant-Speed Time Walk, that will NEVER see tournament play?

2. I do get the timing rules, and frankly I think it would be good to reprint this card to remind people how it actually works and how those timing rules are important to know if you want to be good at the game. Basically, Skill-Testing cards shouldn't be called 'bad cards' just because only a good player will know how to use them and a new player will 'feel bad'.

Know what the answer is to Salient's problem?

7. "Here. Let me show you what you should have done. We'll take the game back to the moment when I drew my card for the turn. Right now, you have priority and can take away my lands for the turn. If you wait until I've tapped my lands, you don't have priority."

If it's a tournament, fine I get why you wouldn't want to do that Salient, but then people should be advised to not play tournaments until they know the rules, AND tournaments should have a "Learn to Play Magic" corner that showcases cards like this with tricky rules. Knowing when and how to play mana short is a fun experience for people looking to strategize. Being told that some people don't get how a card works and therefore it's ''unfun'' undermines the ability of strategists to learn and grow in their way.

And leads to every "Top" Deck of the modern era being named "Junk" because they win by being full of ***. :P Midrange is lame, I want Classic Control AND Classic Aggro back -_-

25567: Mana Short.author: Xycolian
25567: Mana Short.text_parsed:
This card is great in all stages of the game, but I think it really shines in late game. but only if you're running a control deck.

If you're running a control deck, this card is basically a free turn, because if you've been controlling your opponent properly, they will have no board presence, so they won't have any creatures to attack with or anything else. Manlands don't even stand up to this card, which is nice.

During late game, the cost is so low that if an opponent tries to sneak an instant through, you'll have enough excess mana to counter it.

Kind of surprised this card isn't very expensive (in terms of money).

25568: Equilibrium.author: Lyoncet
25568: Equilibrium.text_parsed:
@GruesomeGoo
"Infinite mana with Priest of Gix"

No. First, you'd need two priests, since Equilibrium triggers when the card is played, not when it resolves; since your first priest is a spell at the time, it's not yet a creature and can't be bounced. Second, you're paying 2B to put him down, getting BBB, then paying 1 to put the other one back in your hand. In other words, you've spent 3B to get BBB. You're now down one mana. There are ways to get infinite combos going with this card, but that's not one of them.

If you added two Cloud Keys and chose creatures, you could get an infinite mana combo going. Or this plus Priest of Gix x2 plus Aluren.
25568: Equilibrium.text_posted:
@GruesomeGoo
[i]"Infinite mana with [autocard]Priest of Gix[/autocard]"[/i]

No.  First, you'd need two priests, since [autocard]Equilibrium[/autocard] triggers when the card is played, not when it resolves; since your first priest is a spell at the time, it's not yet a creature and can't be bounced.  Second, you're paying 2B to put him down, getting BBB, then paying 1 to put the other one back in your hand.  In other words, you've spent 3B to get BBB.  You're now down one mana.  There are ways to get infinite combos going with this card, but that's not one of them.

If you added two [autocard]Cloud Key[/autocard]s and chose creatures, you could get an infinite mana combo going.  Or this plus [autocard]Priest of Gix[/autocard] x2 plus [autocard]Aluren[/autocard].

25568: Equilibrium.author: AssKickingBoots
25568: Equilibrium.text_parsed:
The first rare I ever drew and still one of my favorites. Combos incredibly well with Aluren.

I built a deck around that combo utilizing cards with ETB card draw effects that cost 3 cmc or less, like Carven Caryatid, Wall of Blossoms, Wall of Omens, and Coiling Oracle. Since it is already a defender heavy deck, I use Overgrown Battlement for mana-ramp. I use Sterling Grove to tutor and/or protect the key enchantments. Lightning Greaves allows for infinite mana abuse by after I pop the Battlements in and out of play with the Aluren/Equilibrium combo.

Typical result, anywhere from turn 5 to turn 8 I'm able to go through my deck at will to drop my win condition: an unblockable (due to either Venser, the Sojourner or Jhessian Balmgiver) Primalcrux with a couple Khalni Hydras and/or an arbitrarily large Omnath, Locus of Mana.

The great thing about this deck is, while it sounds needlessly complex, the combo works well with just a few pieces and gets better with each piece added to it.

Since it is already a defender heavy deck, I use [autocard]Overgrown Battlement[/autocard] for mana-ramp. I use [autocard]Sterling Grove[/autocard] to tutor and/or protect the key enchantments. [autocard]Lightning Greaves[/autocard] allows for infinite mana abuse by after I pop the Battlements in and out of play with the Aluren/Equilibrium combo.

The great thing about this deck is, while it sounds needlessly complex, the combo works well with just a few pieces and gets better with each piece added to it.

25593: Elvish Archers.text_parsed:
I think its Rare because green didn't have a lot of First Strikers and It's a Savannah Lions for an extra 1 that gives it first strike.

Doing a quick search for green first strike shows just over a page of green cards that have or give/gain first strike, if you remove all the gold and look at only mono green cards you have 12 cards, 11 creatures one enchant creature(Mammoth Harness) only 5 of the creatures natively have first strike and 2 of those are legends, the other 6 have some condition that needs to be met for first strike to be gained...

25624: Corrupt.author: True_Mumin
25624: Corrupt.text_parsed:
Man, I couldn't agree more! I love Corrupt, it's wicked, but the 7th Edition art is just... I mean, what is that bland, uncool black mage even DOING in this picture? Why are there two soldiers, the spell only works on one target! And looking at that stupid *ss face in the corner p*sses me off every time. It's not supposed to be even remotely funny, dammit! This spell is pure evil! I usually don't whine about artwork much, but this one makes me feel bad playing the card. Yes, I've seen a LOT worse Magic art, but this one... it just doesn't fit. AT ALL. Plus the whole scene is really poorly planned-out, the focus is on, what, the mage? The sword? The black thingy which is apparently hurting(?) the soldiers? I don't know, your whole attention is instantly drawn to that friggin' FACE in the corner. And the damn white borders make it even worse (I'm so glad they finally decided to kill them, no one ever liked them). Corrupt is one of the main win condition spells in my MBC and unfortunately, since I only have the 7th Edition ones, it looks like s**t. Thank you, Wizards, for reprinting it with a much more appropriate artwork AND rarity. Black power!
*Goes off to buy a playset of Shadowmoor Corrupts*

Oh, and the textless version of Corrupt is terrific, look it up.
25624: Corrupt.text_posted:
Man, I couldn't agree more! I love Corrupt, it's wicked, but the 7th Edition art is just... I mean, what is that bland, uncool black mage even DOING in this picture? Why are there two soldiers, the spell only works on one target! And looking at that stupid *ss face in the corner p*sses me off every time. It's not supposed to be even remotely funny, dammit! This spell is pure evil! I usually don't whine about artwork much, but this one makes me feel bad playing the card. Yes, I've seen a LOT worse Magic art, but this one... it just doesn't fit. AT ALL. Plus the whole scene is really poorly planned-out, the focus is on, what, the mage? The sword? The black thingy which is apparently hurting(?) the soldiers? I don't know, your whole attention is instantly drawn to that friggin' FACE in the corner. And the damn white borders make it even worse (I'm so glad they finally decided to kill them, no one ever liked them). Corrupt is one of the main win condition spells in my MBC and unfortunately, since I only have the 7th Edition ones, it looks like s**t. Thank you, Wizards, for reprinting it with a much more appropriate artwork AND rarity. Black power!
*Goes off to buy a playset of Shadowmoor Corrupts*

Oh, and the textless version of Corrupt is terrific, look it up.

@ internetNinjacy
Black's "deal" with green and white in general has to do with parts of what they represent.

Green is growth. Black is decay.

White is life. Black is death.

Besides, there's plenty of white hate towards black and red, and green hate towards black and blue, and red hate of blue and white. Every color has two colors that they just don't get along with, and so a lot of color-specific hate ends up there.

25634: Fugue.author: DrJack
25634: Fugue.text_parsed:
This one wins the grand prize for Art That Doesn't Match Its Name (Or Its Function!).

(OK, thanks to you guys, now I know that there is another definition of "fugue". Still, wouldn't it be cool to have a card with a shadowy dude playing a fugue on a skeletal pipe organ or something?)

Fugue: A dude swinging a sword around, that makes you discard 3 cards? After first hearing about this card I was expecting to see someone playing a pipe organ - you know, playing a "fugue", which is a piece of music written in a particular style for those that don't know. Being a black card, I was expecting (and hoping) for a ghostly outlined form sitting at a spooky looking pipe organ, perhaps looking over his shoulder and giving you a impish smile. Discarding 3 cards could sort of make sense, being that a fugue has at least 3 "voices" (melodic lines that interact and trade-off parts). Is that what the card designer was originally thinking?

Boys, it's time for you to get acquainted with J.S. Bach's "Well Tempered Klavier" books and listen to some performances of the prelude & fugues contained within. They're transcendant, after all.
25634: Fugue.text_posted:
This one wins the grand prize for Art That Doesn't Match Its Name (Or Its Function!).

(OK, thanks to you guys, now I know that there is another definition of "fugue". Still, wouldn't it be cool to have a card with a shadowy dude playing a fugue on a skeletal pipe organ or something?)

Fugue: A dude swinging a sword around, that makes you discard 3 cards? After first hearing about this card I was expecting to see someone playing a pipe organ - you know, playing a "fugue", which is a piece of music written in  a particular style for those that don't know. Being a black card, I was expecting (and hoping) for a ghostly outlined form sitting at a spooky looking pipe organ, perhaps looking over his shoulder and giving you a impish smile. Discarding 3 cards could sort of make sense, being that a fugue has at least 3 "voices" (melodic lines that interact and trade-off parts). Is that what the card designer was originally thinking?

Boys, it's time for you to get acquainted with J.S. Bach's "Well Tempered Klavier" books and listen to some performances of the prelude & fugues contained within. They're transcendant, after all.

25635: Necrologia.author: themlsna
25635: Necrologia.text_parsed:
This is a really good card, but there are two things that stop me from making this my first choice for black draw:
1) I'm already having to pay x life to draw, so 5 mana is a bit much in the cost. The reason I'm willing to pay life is because I'm getting a bargain in the mana department, usually.
2) The restriction on timing. You can't really use this to get an answer to something your opponent is harassing you with. I'm not saying I think this should have been an instant, but I can't use the cards I draw until the next turn? I can't even flash it in with Lelyine.

Still, if you have good board position and are just looking to draw into combo pieces or win cards, then this is a decent option, but not the best.

25635: Necrologia.author: Elvoran
25635: Necrologia.text_parsed:
@DarthParallax.
On the rules of Transcendence;
If your life total is 20 or more and you control an effect that states "you can't lose the game", then an infinite loop is formed. If neither player wants to end the loop by removing one of these two cards from the battlefield, the game ends in a draw.

25635: Necrologia.author: Ferlord
25635: Necrologia.text_parsed:
Anybody? Really?

No one has suggested this yet?

I've won 4 games of EDH using this cheap-ass strategy: Necrologia and Psychosis Crawler. Make sure your life is higher than everyone else's (Maybe some help from Venser's Journal?) and then play it. This can call for a turn 6 EDH victory... against EVERYONE.

EG:
Turn 1-4: land.
Turn 5: Psychosis Crawler.
Turn 6: (you draw, then lose 1 life) Necrologia. Pay 39 life, GAME OVER.

Although, my deck has become infamous alongside the people I play EDH with, so they hold onto their counters when I ever consider playing Psychosis Crawler.

Moral of the Story: Don't play Necrologia like a D**k.... or do, whether you want victory or friends.

25637: Crypt Rats.author: Chrs84
25637: Crypt Rats.text_parsed:
the pestilence effect on a creature, opens up the black pump game, gives you a few more ways to play the style... of course the drawback is a bit different, since crypt will take damage as well.. so protect him, or regenerate, but even more to black's nature is the spells available to bring a creature back from the graveyd.... this is a super solid spell.... more? how about trying to mix into the flow of your game ways for spells to be recycled while not significantly altering your theme/deck... how about persist?... especially if one would play with seal of strength (getting rats above their 1/1) ... anyway, you get the point, as a creature it's usually easier to find ways to play it many times during a game... so the more times your opponent deals with crypt rats perhaps another aspect of your game gets a bit more breathing room to trigger.

a great looking card as well.... generally a very fair casting cost.. it just kind of had to fall within 3 or 4 mana... does anyone think it could have gotten away with 2 black to cast? (I don't think it could)... anyway the difficulty is that it's a 1/1.. Most of the time you won't mind losing them so long as they can stay for the duration/during your actual use/activation... still... if your creatures or a creature or next spell could be played as if it had flash... well I'm sure you could take it from there lol

yes vampiric link is excellent for the crypt rats !!

25637: Crypt Rats.author: NV.Collis
25637: Crypt Rats.text_parsed:
Crypt Rats is a great card in a deck able to tap most lands for black mana. So long as you make a deck that can fit it, and come on.... what else is black good at if not building a deck that can get your creatures back from the great beyond faster that your non black opponent (or make use of the poor souls lost to Crypt Rats furry)?

Good decks are full of biffy creatures and high cost cards (I'm over exaggerating to make a point here... don't go ape crazy on me!), great decks take a card like Crypt Rats and build around it.

I, in a humble attempt tried to do just this.

Its a combo deck based off Crypt Rats equipped with Scythe of the Wretched while having a mana creature on the field (ie Blood Vassal) and a life gaining creature (I use a Dross Harvester... for personal taste reasons) and now your off to infinite fun... well not infinite fun as the combo is infinite but your opponents life totals aren't....

And If you have a hard time playing off the combo due to Crypt Rats getting hated by all the other players, fear not! Thats why you add a Necrotic Ooze to the mix and a Will-o'-the-Wisp in your graveyard for good measure.

Any ways heres a link to my 'Wretched Rats' deck for your viewing pleasure! Leave comments if you like it, change it to work for you and have fun in multi-player casual games!

http://www.essentialmagic.com//Decks/View.asp?ID=830159

Cheers NV!

25641: Oppression.author: Ferlord
25641: Oppression.text_parsed:
This is such a good card for slowing down a game, especially EDH.

playing this on my first turn with dark ritual granted me "Target No.1" status and i was first to fall...

by about turn 40 XD.

See, no one wanted to play anything because they'd lose all their good cards, right? And since my EDH deck revolved around resurrection, i didn't care when i discarded Demon of Death's Gate or Sheoldred, Whispering One

Regardless, i think this card is very good, despite the back-firing effect is has on yourself. Not as good of an enchantment as No Mercy, but still does it's job.

25642: Greed.author: Ferlord
25642: Greed.text_parsed:
This is essentially a more expensive Yawgmoth's Bargain-esque card drawer for a cheaper CMC.

Is it better? Erm... arguable. 1 Life per card is very cheap, and thus is why the Bargain is banned in EDH. Greed, however, requires not only 2 life, but 1 black mana. Although, you still get a draw phase.

I like Greed, though. It provides another card drawing mechanic in EDH besides Phyrexian Arena (plus any others that I can't think of)

25643: Tainted Aether.author: HoboNumber4
25643: Tainted Aether.text_parsed:
One of my personal favorite cards. Have a fun Johnny-ish deck based around it that runs:

Tainted Aether
Blood Seeker
Countersquall
Barrin's Spite
Unsummon
Dark Ritual
Phyrexian Arena
Echoing Truth
Clutch of the Undercity (transmute for Tainted Aether, and useful on its own if you have more than one TA out already)
Hunted Horror
Hunted Phantasm
Forbidden Orchard

In the deck, bouncing your opponent's creatures is more efficient than destroying them, and his or her death (often) comes from the constant creatures you "gift" them. A very satisfying way to kill someone.

25643: Tainted Aether.text_parsed: Edit: This card is a powerhouse in the right deck. Gifting creatures and bouncing can create a very solid lock or even a concede by as early as turn 3 depending on your starting hand. Dark Ritual, Hunted Horror, Hunted Phantasm, and Warped Devotion work so well together its absurd. Use Echoing Truth to bounce the tokens to make them discard, and then proceed to smash face. I actually have been using a Tainted Aether deck for a while now, and find it quite fun. If you ever get two or more of these out, once you place a single Hunted Phantasm there is no going back for your opponent, if you bounce them sacrificing ten lands and/or creatures is huge.

25645: Stronghold Assassin.author: ICEFANG13
25645: Stronghold Assassin.text_parsed:
Although I wish this would work with Grave Pact it doesn't (I wish Grave Pact worked with Deathspore Thallid.)

Once you sac a creature and choose the target (say a Saproling) Grave Pact's ability goes on the stack and it now above Stronghold's effect, it resolves first and the other player has to sac a creature, he can sac any of them, but since you are killing the Saproling anyway, it makes the most sense to sac the Saproling and counter the effect.

25645: Stronghold Assassin.author: FreakyMutantMan
25645: Stronghold Assassin.text_parsed: @alextfish The art for the original printing depicts an assassin who is very obviously undead. Creature types on old cards were given a huge update some time ago to bring them in line with modern standards; before that, Stronghold Assassin was exclusively an Assassin. Given this and how Seventh Edition has been noted to possess a number of issues with regards to art and flavor, the undeadness wasn't preserved for Seventh Edition most likely because they were not aware it would matter later on, and might not have cared much to do so anyway.

25645: Stronghold Assassin.author: Aquillion
25645: Stronghold Assassin.text_parsed: @ICEFANG13: Grave Pact does work with Deathspore Thallid. Tokens are removed from the game after they end up in another zone; but they still hit that zone first, so a token will trigger "goes to the graveyard" effects even though it vanished the moment it arrived there.
25645: Stronghold Assassin.text_posted: @ICEFANG13:  [autocard]Grave Pact[/autocard] does work with [autocard]Deathspore Thallid[/autocard].  Tokens are removed from the game [i]after[/i] they end up in another zone; but they still hit that zone first, so a token will trigger "goes to the graveyard" effects even though it vanished the moment it arrived there.

25657: Pit Trap.author: Kaizeischi
25657: Pit Trap.text_parsed: Surprised this has such a low rating! Colorless, regenerationless creature destruction? People went crazy over torch in their sideboards, this deserves more credit. Limitations kinda set it back, especially the inability to kill flying, but it's really a threat to any big attacker. I feel that showing off your destruction like this, even if it can be killed in advance, really set back an opponent mentally several turns. Even if he has 2-3, you have your choice if he wants to hit with everyone.

25661: Grafted Skullcap.author: CeremonialBathory
25661: Grafted Skullcap.text_parsed: @Test-Subject_217601 - Yes, but what you do normally during your draw step and what this card has you do is different. What it really means is that "During your draw step, you draw an additional card". It's just worded this way so that stacking them makes more sense. So if you had three of these out, you'd draw four cards during your draw step. But this is amazing for Hellbent like Wusanderz said.
25661: Grafted Skullcap.text_posted: @Test-Subject_217601 - Yes, but what you do [b]normally[/b] during your draw step and what this card has you do is different. What it really means is that "During your draw step, you draw an additional card". It's just worded this way so that stacking them makes more sense. So if you had three of these out, you'd draw four cards during your draw step. But this is amazing for Hellbent like [i]Wusanderz[/i] said.

25663: Storm Cauldron.author: AssKickingBoots
25663: Storm Cauldron.text_parsed:
I just realized this is near perfect with the Lair lands (Rith's Grove, Treva's Ruins, Dromar's Cavern, Darigaaz's Caldera, Crosis's Catacombs).

The ruling on Lairs is that you can tap them for mana before you return a land or sacrifice it. With Storm Cauldron out, you drop the Lair, it's ETB effect goes on the stack, you tap it for mana, Storm Cauldron's triggered ability goes on the stack in front of and resolves before the ETB effect, the Lair is safely in your hand.

Both the Lairs and this work great with Landfall anyway.
25663: Storm Cauldron.text_posted:
I just realized this is near perfect with the Lair lands ([autocard]Rith's Grove[/autocard], [autocard]Treva's Ruins[/autocard], [autocard]Dromar's Cavern[/autocard], [autocard]Darigaaz's Caldera[/autocard], [autocard]Crosis's Catacombs[/autocard]).

The ruling on Lairs is that you can tap them for mana [i]before[/i] you return a land or sacrifice it. With Storm Cauldron out, you drop the Lair, it's ETB effect goes on the stack, you tap it for mana, Storm Cauldron's triggered ability goes on the stack in front of and resolves before the ETB effect, the Lair is safely in your hand.

Both the Lairs and this work great with Landfall anyway.

25664: Feroz's Ban.author: Mode
25664: Feroz's Ban.text_parsed:
Wondering why this card has such a high mana cost that makes it quite unappealing since this won't help you in lategame anymore?
Well, being designed in Homelands, and following the principle that cards from this set suck in general, not many questions left about this card, are there?

If this card reduced the cost by only and had a mana cost of just as Sphere of Resistance, Thorn of Amethyst or Defense Grid this would find much more play and could proof somewhat useful against aggro decks.
I'm actually confident Wizards is going to provide us with such an artifact someday.
Back then in (the) Homelands (of overcautiously designed cards) it just wasn't the right time to do so.

If this card reduced the cost by [1] only and had a mana cost of [2] just as [autocard]Sphere of Resistance[/autocard], [autocard]Thorn of Amethyst[/autocard] or [autocard]Defense Grid[/autocard] this would find much more play and could proof somewhat useful against aggro decks.
I'm actually confident Wizards is going to provide us with such an artifact someday.
Back then in [i](the)[/i] Homelands [i](of overcautiously designed cards)[/i] it just wasn't the right time to do so.

25676: Goblin War Drums.author: Clash25
25676: Goblin War Drums.text_parsed: If you are attacking with a red creature and have Goblin War Drums, and the defending player has one creature with protection from red, can they still block that red creature?
25676: Goblin War Drums.text_posted: If you are attacking with a red creature and have Goblin War Drums, and the defending player has one creature with protection from red, can they still block that red creature?

25676: Goblin War Drums.author: Krispyz
25676: Goblin War Drums.text_parsed:
@Clash25, No you would not be able to block that creature. War drums creates a world affect, it is not targeting any creatures so protection would not negate the ability. It is the same for creatures with this affect. For example, Phyrexian Colossus cannot be blocked by fewer than three creatures. One creature with protection from artifacts is not an exception to this ability.

EDIT: Also, I absolutely love this card. I have it in my Rith EDH deck swinging with a ton of tokens. Combine it with War Cadence and mass creatures can quickly become unblockable.
25676: Goblin War Drums.text_posted:
@Clash25, No you would not be able to block that creature. War drums creates a world affect, it is not targeting any creatures so protection would not negate the ability. One creature with protection from artifacts is not an exception to this ability.

EDIT: Also, I absolutely love this card. I have it in my Rith EDH deck swinging with a ton of tokens. Combine it with [autocard]War Cadence[/autocard] and mass creatures can quickly become unblockable.
